description:
Norovirus GII/Hu/JP/2011/GII/Yuzawa/Gira2HS is a strain of norovirus that belongs to genogroup II (GII), which is the most common genogroup of norovirus found in humans. This specific strain was first identified in Japan in 2011.

Noroviruses are small, non-enveloped, single-stranded RNA viruses that are a leading cause of acute gastroenteritis worldwide. They are highly contagious and can be transmitted through the fecal-oral route, contaminated food or water, or direct contact with infected individuals.

The GII/Yuzawa/Gira2HS strain has been classified based on its genomic sequence, which is used to differentiate between the various norovirus strains and genotypes. Genetic analysis can provide insights into the evolution, epidemiology, and potential virulence of this particular strain.

Further research on the Norovirus GII/Hu/JP/2011/GII/Yuzawa/Gira2HS strain may contribute to a better understanding of norovirus diversity, transmission dynamics, and the development of effective prevention and control strategies against this important public health concern.
